Estimates of Causal Effects. Chetty and Hendren (2015) estimate gender-specific causal effects of spending an additional year growing up in each CZ by analyzing families who move across CZs. Their estimates are identified from differences in the ages at which children move to different CZs. Intuitively, if children who move from New York to Boston do better as adults the earlier they move, one can infer that growing up in Boston has a positive causal effect relative to New York.

Note that Chetty and Hendren (2015) do not compute causal effects on employment rates for children who grow up low-income families. Instead, they estimate effects on individual income ranks at age 26 for children whose parents are at the 25th percentile of the parental income distribution. Individual income is defined as the sum of individual W-2 wage earnings, UI benefits, SSDI payments, and half of household self-employment income (see Online Appendix A of Chetty et al.
